title: Holy Infant of Atocha
text:
Holy Infant of Atocha or Santo Niño de Atocha is a <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> image of the <a href="Christ%20Child">Christ Child</a> popular among the <a href="Hispanic">Hispanic</a> cultures of <a href="Spain">Spain</a>, Latin America and the southwestern United States. It is distinctly characterized by a basket he carries, along with a staff, drinking gourd (He used the gourd to carry water, and a basket of bread that he fed to prisoners who were thirsty and hungry) and a cape to which is affixed a scallop shell, symbol of <a href="Camino%20de%20Santiago">a pilgrimage to Saint James</a>.
History.
Devotion to Holy Infant of Atocha originally began as a Marian devotion with a medieval statue of the <a href="Madonna%20and%20Child">Madonna and Child</a> in <a href="Toledo%2C%20Spain">Toledo, Spain</a>. According to Juan Javier Pescador, it originally reflected devotions to three different depictions of the Virgin Mary: Our Lady of Atocha, Our Lady of Antigua, and Our Lady of Pregnancies that later coalesced into Our Lady of Atocha.
The image of the Divine Child was detachable, and devout families would often borrow the image of the infant when a woman was about to give birth to her child.
In the 13th century, much of Spain was under <a href="Al-Andalus">Muslim rule</a>. The town of <a href="Atocha%20%28Madrid%29">Atocha</a>, now part of Madrid's <a href="Arganzuela">Arganzuela</a> district, was lost to the <a href="Muslims">Muslims</a>, and many Christians there were taken prisoners as spoils of war. The Christian prisoners were not fed by the jailers, but by family members who brought them food. According to pious legend, the caliph ordered that only children under the age of 12 were permitted to bring food. Conditions became increasingly difficult for those men without small children. The women of Atocha prayed before the statue of Our Lady of Atocha at a nearby parish, a title of the <a href="Blessed%20Virgin%20Mary">Blessed Virgin Mary</a>, to ask her son <a href="Jesus">Jesus</a> for help.
Reports soon began among the people of Atocha that an unknown child under the age of twelve and dressed in pilgrim's clothing had begun to bring food to childless prisoners at night. The women of the town returned to Our Lady of Atocha to thank the Virgin for her intercession and noticed that the shoes worn by the Infant Jesus were tattered and dusty. They replaced the shoes of the Infant Jesus, but these became worn again. The people of Atocha took this as a sign that it was the Infant Jesus who went out every night to help those in need.
Description.
The Holy Child of Atocha is depicted dressed as a boy pilgrim dressed in a brown cloak with a white lace collar over a blue robe. He wears a brimmed hat with a plume and carries a basket full of bread in one hand and a pilgrim's staff in the other. The pilgrim's staff is often depicted with a water gourd fastened to it. On the cloak he wears a Shell of Saint James, the symbol of the pilgrims to the Shrine of <a href="Santiago%20de%20Compostela%20Cathedral">Santiago de Compostela</a> in northwestern Spain. The Child is said to roam the hills and valleys, particularly at night, bringing aid and comfort to the needy, and thereby wearing out his shoes. He is usually shown seated.
Devotion beyond Atocha.
The Moorish conflict extended well beyond the town of Atocha. During dire points in their journey, travelers reported that a young boy, dressed as a pilgrim, would come to them bringing food and other necessities. The boy would often travel with them until they were out of danger and then guide them to the safest roads to reach their destination. Pious legends continued to be developed and the miraculous Child later became considered to be the <a href="Child%20Jesus">Child Jesus</a> and was given the title the "Holy Child of Atocha".
North America.
There is a shrine run by the Poor Clares, dedicated to Niño de Atocha at <a href="Plateros%2C%20Zacatecas">Plateros</a>, near the city of <a href="Fresnillo">Fresnillo</a>, in the state of <a href="Zacatecas">Zacatecas</a>, Mexico. In 1554, the original Mexican Niño de Atocha was brought from Atocha to Zacatecas, and installed in the church of Saint Augustine not long after a silver strike in Plateros. 
In those years silver was discovered in Fresnillo and mines were being opened in the mountains near the settlement. Within a few weeks of the opening of the mine of Fresnillo, there was an explosion and many miners were trapped. The wives of the miners went to the church of St. Augustine to pray for their husbands and noticed that the child on the image of Our Lady of Atocha was missing. At the same time, it was said that a child came to the trapped miners, gave them water and showed them the way out of the mine. Whenever there was a problem at the mine the child helped the miners in need. Each time this happened, the image of the child on the Virgin's arms was found to be dirty and his clothes had little holes in them. After that, the Holy Child was taken off his mother's arms and put on a glass box for everyone to see. The Holy Child of Atocha has become a symbol of <a href="Zacatecas">Zacatecas</a> and the protector of miners. Many make pilgrimages to Plateros at Christmas to bring toys to the Holy Child.
A second shrine is located in and at <a href="Chimayo%2C%20New%20Mexico">Chimayo, New Mexico</a>, USA.
In 1998, an outdoor shrine to "El Niño de Atocha" was established at <a href="La%20Iglesia%20de%20Nuestra%20Se%C3%B1ora%20la%20Reina%20de%20los%20%C3%81ngeles">La Iglesia de Nuestra Señora la Reina de los Ángeles</a> in downtown Los Angeles, California.
The Philippines.
Holy Infant of Atocha is also popular among the <a href="Filipino%20people">Filipino Catholics</a>. The local variant, simply known as "Santo Niño" (Holy Child), is portrayed very similarly to the Spanish Atocha, except that it is always standing rather than sitting. He bears a staff with an attached bag or basket, which is usually filled with coins or candy, and he dons a pilgrim hat resembling the Atocha image.
The current "Santo Niño" found in many Filipino homes is traditionally dressed in either green or red garments. In Filipino <a href="Folk%20Catholicism">Folk Catholicism</a>, red garments are suited for images enshrined at home, while green ones are for those enshrined in business establishments; a common offering to the latter is a bowl filled with coins and sweets. In addition, many Filipinos customarily dress the "Santo Niño" in modern attire that reflects their professional roles, such as nurses, doctors, janitors, teachers, and policemen, as a means of asking for his patronage. These customs relating to dress are also applied to replicas of the <a href="Santo%20Ni%C3%B1o%20de%20Cebu">Santo Niño de Cebu</a>, brought by <a href="Ferdinand%20Magellan">Ferdinand Magellan</a> to the islands in 1521, and the <a href="Infant%20Jesus%20of%20Prague">Infant Jesus of Prague</a>.
Pop culture and other references.
In the film "<a href="Napoleon%20Dynamite">Napoleon Dynamite</a>", Pedro suggests placing <a href="Santo%20%28art%29">santos</a> around the hallways of his high school, recommending "El Santo Niño de Atocha". He says that his Aunt Concha has seen him.
Holy Infant of Atocha is sometimes associated with the Yoruba orisha <a href="Eshu">Eshu</a>, or Elegua.
This holy infant appears in the 1991 novel "Mojo and the Pickle Jar", by Douglas Bell.
In <a href="Michael%20Jackson">Michael Jackson</a>'s video for "<a href="Beat%20It">Beat It</a>", there is a picture of the Santo Niño above his bed.
On the television sitcom "<a href="George%20Lopez%20%28TV%20series%29">George Lopez</a>", the Holy Infant of Atocha is displayed in the family's kitchen.
The Colombian television historical drama "<a href="Escobar%2C%20el%20Patr%C3%B3n%20del%20Mal">Escobar, el Patrón del Mal</a>" features references to the Holy Infant of Atocha. The saint is a particular favorite of Pablo Escobar's mother, Emilia Hermilda Gaviria. She displays a very large portrait of the saint (same as the image above) in her foyer and invokes him in verbal blessings upon her loved ones.
See also.
8. Santo Nino de Atocha is referenced in the University of New Mexico Press book @Copyright 1997, (read per third printing, 1998)The Circuit, stories from the life of a migrant child. The believable story is written by the grown child himself, Francisco Jimenez. The story begins with the family leaving a “barren” area of Mexico and beginning life again in California, where they sometimes find farm work and other times have to leave and search further. Meanwhile, as the family grows and weaves their growing family together their youngest, an infant gets what even the hospital doctor considers deathly ill. Where answers are not answers and only faith in the impossible aligns, they pray and win together with Santo Nino de Atocha. Who is brought to life in this story? Every one of them… and certainly they are strengthened as a family.
